question_stem: The function \(f(x)\) is defined as \(f(x) = \frac{2x - 1}{x + 5}\) for \(x \neq -5\).

parts.question_text: Write down the equations of the asymptotes of the curve \(y = f(x)\).
parts.solution_text:
The vertical asymptote occurs when the denominator is zero, so \(x + 5 = 0\), giving \(x = -5\).
As \(x\) tends to infinity, \(f(x)\) approaches \(\frac{2x}{x} = 2\). Therefore, the horizontal asymptote is \(y = 2\).
The equations of the asymptotes are \(x = -5\) and \(y = 2\).
